speaker: Teacher
text: We're doing peer feedback on your essays today. Remember to be constructive and specific.

speaker: Emma Johnson
text: I'm a little nervous about sharing my essay. I worked really hard on it but I'm not sure it's good enough.

speaker: Marcus Williams
text: I feel the same way. But getting feedback will help us improve, right?

speaker: Sarah Chen
text: Definitely. And we're all learning together. No one's essay is perfect on the first draft.

speaker: Ava Wilson
text: Emma, I read your introduction and I really liked how you hooked the reader with that personal story.

speaker: Emma Johnson
text: Thank you! I wasn't sure if it was too personal.

speaker: Ava Wilson
text: No, it made it relatable. One suggestion though - in paragraph three, you could add more evidence to support your main argument.

speaker: Emma Johnson
text: Oh, you're right. I kind of rushed through that part. I'll add some examples from the text we read.

speaker: Alicia Rivera
text: Marcus, your essay has a really strong argument. The way you organized your points is very logical.

speaker: Marcus Williams
text: Thanks Alicia. I spent a lot of time on the outline.

speaker: Alicia Rivera
text: It shows! One thing - have you considered a counterargument section? It might make your position even stronger.

speaker: Marcus Williams
text: I hadn't thought of that. Where would you put it?

speaker: Alicia Rivera
text: Maybe after your second main point? You could acknowledge what critics might say, then explain why your view is still valid.

speaker: Marcus Williams
text: That's a great idea. I'm going to try that. Thanks for the suggestion!

speaker: Sarah Chen
text: Can I get feedback on my conclusion? I feel like it's too abrupt.

speaker: Ethan Rodriguez
text: Let me read it... I see what you mean. You summarize your points but then it just ends. Maybe add a sentence about why this topic matters?

speaker: Sarah Chen
text: Like connecting it to real life or the bigger picture?

speaker: Ethan Rodriguez
text: Exactly! That would give readers something to think about after they finish.

speaker: Sarah Chen
text: That makes sense. I can see how that would make it feel more complete. Thanks Ethan!

speaker: Ava Wilson
text: I'm really glad we did this. Everyone gave such helpful feedback without being mean about it.

speaker: Emma Johnson
text: I agree. I was nervous at first, but now I feel like I know exactly how to improve my essay.

speaker: Teacher
text: This is exactly what constructive peer feedback should look like. You all did an excellent job.
